newsitem.title: NEPAL: Three Icelanders among 12 to reach top of Everest.
newsitem.headline: Three Icelanders among 12 to reach top of Everest.

text.p: Three Icelanders have reached the summit of Mount Everest to become the first from their country to conquer the world's tallest peak, Nepal's Ministry of Tourism announced on Friday.

It said Bjorn Olafsson, a 30-year-old computer programmer, Einar Kristjan Stefansson, a 31-year-old engineer and Hallgrimur Magnusson, a rescue worker who celebrates his 34th birthday on Saturday, reached the summit on Wednesday afternoon. All three are from the Icelandic capital Reykjavik.

Another member of the British-Icelandic-Mexican expedition, Nikola Kekus, a 40-year-old engineer from Cumbria in Britain, also made it to the top with the Icelanders, along with two Nepali Sherpas, the ministry said.
Two climbers from a Canadian expedition reached the summit of the 8,848 metre (29,029 foot) Everest, called Sagarmatha by Nepalis, on Friday, the tourism ministry said.
Jamie Clarke, 29, and Alan Hobson, 39, both from Calgary, led four Sherpas in two successful assaults on the peak early on Friday, it said.
A ministry official said: "More climbers are expected to reach the summit today."
Malaysian television showed live coverage of two Malaysian climbers, M. Magendran and N. Mohandas, who planted their nation's flag on the summit of Everest on Friday.
Two people have died this spring on the Nepali side of Everest and five have died on the Tibetan side.
